an3.123:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings.
an3.123:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an3.123:5.1: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
an3.123:5.2: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for tomorrow’s meal.
an3.123:5.3: The mendicant accepts if they want.
an3.123:5.4: When the night has passed, they dress in the morning, take their bowl and robes, and approach that householder’s home,
an3.123:5.5: where they sit on the indicated seat.
an3.123:5.6: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
an3.123:6.2: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods.’
an3.123:6.4: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’
an3.123:6.5: They eat that food tied, stupefied, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
an3.123:6.6: They think about it with sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.
an3.123:6.7: A gift to such a mendicant is not very fruitful, I say.
an3.123:7.1: Take another case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
an3.123:7.2: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for tomorrow’s meal.
an3.123:7.3: The mendicant accepts if they want.
an3.123:7.4: When the night has passed, they dress in the morning, take their bowl and robes, and approach that householder’s home,
an3.123:7.5: where they sit on the indicated seat.
an3.123:7.6: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
an3.123:8.2: ‘It’s so good that the householder or their child serves and satisfies me with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.’
an3.123:8.4: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’
an3.123:8.5: They eat that alms-food untied, unstupefied, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
an3.123:8.6: They think about it with thoughts of renunciation, love, or kindness.
an3.123:8.7: A gift to such a mendicant is very fruitful, I say.
